title: Monday, 1st October 2018
bodyHTML:
11:08 am
BE11:08am

Good musking.

Otter Good morning monday friends
Soundbuy Morning
Blank canvas good morning everyone
Pseudonym Good morning

Welcome to Muskets Live, Muskaville's daily musk around the .... wait, I did this last week.

BE11:09am

Let's catch up with the news.

Early Doors Good morning
Early Doors We're in early doors today !
11:09 am

Seems Tesla has to establish “a new committee of independent directors and put in place additional controls and procedures to oversee Musk’s communications.”

BE11:10am

And how's that going?

Imperial Goldsmith could be worse

You can't silence a dork on a mission, it appears.

VV75 morning
BE11:11am

Anyway, the outcome here seems to be fairly mild

Manxish Morning each
11:12 am
BE11:12am

What's curious is why Elon decided to reject a quiet SEC settlement, then saw the SEC rap sheet, then immediately agreed a noisy SEC settlement.

BE11:13am

Maybe impulse control isn't his strong point? Whatever. Have some sellside to say "settlement is good, Tesla's still bad."

BE11:13am

Canaccord incoming.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We believe Elon Musk and Tesla’s settlement with the SEC is a positive development for Tesla – by installing a new chairman and two independent directors, a major risk for investors will be addressed (corporate governance and an independent BoD). While this change addresses our concerns around governance, we believe it’s still too soon to become more constructive, given what we see are some near-term operational and capital challenges.
We view production expectations may remain too high given the many recent distractions. A reset, which we believe may be Q3, might allow a more constructive stance in the shares. However, at the moment and prior to knowledge of the new Chairman and two directors, we are prudently remaining on the sidelines.

Boutel Morning
Provender I thought the original settlement offered had him stepping down from both chair and CEO? Not surprised he told them to get stuffed if that was the case.
BE11:14am

And Barclays.

BE11:15am

With the unexpected SEC/Tesla/Musk settlement announced on Saturday, we are back to the “red pill vs. blue pill debate” over the underlining fundamentals for the stock. We on the red pill side will continue to focus on what we see the longer-term over - valuation of the shares, while those on the blue pill side will probably see the settlement as vindication, esp. as the shares Monday should regain their Friday losses. With 90 days to comply with the settlement, Tesla is likely in our view to strike a typically bullish tone on the 3Q sales release, shareholder letter and conference call. As a result, we would not be surprised to see the stock rebound over the next few weeks. Nevertheless, we reiterate our UW and $210 price target.

Blackbag99 Thyssen, look closer to spinning off metals
11:16 am
BE11:16am

So good that we can talk about redpill/bluepill stuff in terms of capital markets. So delightful that 4Chan has coloured every corner of our lives.

BE11:17am

Still exposure from civil suits – but a longer dated liability. The filing of the SEC case last week provided a fact base that will be helpful to private litigants to allege sufficient facts to move their cases past summary judgment. Nevertheless, these cases will take years to work through the courts
Focus now on deliveries –we expect 52k.
While our delivery estimate is within guide and likely a tad higher than consensus, we expect in the upcoming sales release form Tesla but lots of language around how logistic delays and car carrier shortages prevented Tesla from delivering even more.

Airborne Cigar @BE - anyone like to explain the red pill / blue pill reference?
BE11:18am

And Cowen.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

The bulls on Tesla will highlight that this is a great outcome for Tesla, which relative to the worst case scenario of Elon Musk being removed as an executive at the company it is However, we continue to have concerns around the company's progress moving forward, notably cash burn, competition and the ability to drive down costs to effectively sell a $35K vehicle. We don't object to more oversight of an eccentric executive, increased Board independence and reigning in the use of Twitter for Elon Musk - our sense is these are things that should have been done at Tesla in the first place and not reliant on SEC intervention.

Boutel I assume the Matrix. Unaware of the 4Chan reference.
Blackbag99 I am assuming a matrix reference. An very ageing reference
Paper Chase https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_pill_and_blue_pill
BE11:20am

And a bit more.

chad_john red pill = reality, blue pill = ignorance
chad_john basically
BE11:21am

■ Given Mr. Musk cannot deny the allegations of his claims from the $420 go private offer, we believe this opens him up to future litigation, notably the class action lawsuits that have already been filed.
■ We question if Mr. Musk's demeanor will change after this settlement. $20mn is a drop in the bucket relative to his net worth. He attempted to call the SEC's bluff and not settle last week according to Reuters because he "would be truthful to himself" and "wouldn't be able to live with a compromise." His tone on the 3Q18 earnings call will be eagerly awaited by investors.
■ We see the settlement likely leading to some near-term stability in Tesla shares; however, we don't see increased short covering in the near term and expect the bull/bear debate to linger given the capital crunch the company is in. While we expect some stability in Tesla shares in the near term, we are anxious to see how the November 2018 and March 2019 debt trades given liquidity concerns and lingering production/delivery challenges.

A. M. @Airborne: as Blackbag99 said, matrix.
chad_john Sort of like fundamentals v technicals... don't @ me.

BE11:25am

Foreign buyers are to be targeted by a new tax on the purchase of new homes, as Theresa May says it "cannot be right" that those who don't live in the UK can buy properties as easily as British residents.

The Prime Minister will announce plans to levy a new stamp duty of up to three per cent on individuals and companies not paying tax in this country.

The proceeds of the tax, which will be applied on top of existing rates, have been earmarked for schemes in the government's rough sleeping strategy.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Story dropped to the Telegraph over the weekend.

BE11:26am

What exactly does it mean, though?

Blackbag99 Foreign buyers and people with drug/mental health issues. Natural bedfellows.
BE11:27am

As it stands, overseas buyers (people and companies) pay no surcharge. This new tax is only estimated to raise £40m to £170m, so is peanuts.

Soundbuy Dirty money deterred by a 3% levy............hmmmm
Blackbag99 Not sure how that gets to grips with rough sleepers
Ethelred I hear that Keith Halliwell is in the running for Tesla Chair job
cheeckychappy That "new" policy was just announced to attract Corbynistas
11:28 am
BE11:28am

And it's shaped in the standard taxation way to raise cash rather than deter anyone doing anything.

Airborne Cigar Thanks, A.M. That one never worked for me - I think Bloom County should be on there somewhere...
BE11:28am

UBS comes at us with this example:

BE11:29am

To illustrate the impact this has, we show an example of a £2m property purchase, from the perspective of a foreigner and non-primary residence. Currently, the base stamp duty (i.e. if the property is your primary residence) is 7.7%. An additional surcharge of 3% is levied on buy-to-let and second property. At the high end of the range, a 3% surcharge on foreign buyers would increase the total to 13.7% or £274k. As a comparison, before December 2014, this would have been 7% or £140k.

cheeckychappy The reality is they should be taxing those foreign buyers paying for properties above, say £10 million, a lot more than 3pc IF THEY DON'T LIVE IN THE PROPERTY FOR MORE THAN SIX TO NINE MONTHS OF THE YEAR.
11:29 am
BE11:29am

Strictly anecdotally, I thought the foreign buyers were no longer in the £2m end of the market. They were more in the £300k end of the market because that's where you can get a rental yield.

BE11:30am

Anyway, problem for Berkeley but not really for anyone else.

Ethelred BE more than offset by £ devaluation since 2014
BE11:30am

While the proposed tax is nationwide, this is effectively a London relevant tax which is where the majority of foreign buyer activity takes place. The market here has already been slow for the past 2 years, and further taxation will likely lead to a further slowing in transactions. From the perspective of the homebuilders, we think an additional tax would likely have to be absorbed through price reduction. In our coverage, Berkeley Group has the largest exposure to London (over 80%) and around 50% of buyers are foreigners. CapCo may also be negatively impacted on its Earl's Court scheme.

BE11:36am

Morgan Stanley incoming:

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Ryanair has issued a press release this morning downgrading FY19 net income guidance range from €1.25-1.35bn to €1.1-1.2bn (ex Laudamotion) owing primarily to strike impacts experienced in September as well as impacts on forward bookings into the 3Q19. Consensus expectations have already ticked slightly below the €1.25bn end of the prior guidance (now at €1.234bn according to Bloomberg); however, the company alludes to the possibility of further adjustments if more union actions occur into the 2H19. The company now expects 2Q19 yields to be down 3% (vs +1% previously), while 2H19 yields are now expected to be down 2% vs flat previously. In addition, 2H19 capacity will be cut (by 100bp) lowering FY19 traffic expectations from 139m to 138m. Eindhoven & Bremen bases will close (6 aircraft), and Niederrhein will be cut from 5 to 3 aircraft. Fuel guidance - the company now expects c. €460m increase vs €430m previously. Overall, the company does not comment on market trading/demand changes just the impact of their own employee actions, but we expect consensus to mark to market estimate around 10% today.

Blackbag99 Its still too soon for a Malaysian joke!

BE11:39am

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

[D]ownward pressure on WPP’s multiple has been amplified by concerns
over financial leverage and strategic sprawl. A partial break up could resolve both of these concerns in relatively short order and therefore could be the catalyst for a rerating. Coupled with the scope for an improving revenue growth profile over the balance of the year, we think risk/reward on WPP tilts much more favourably than the market currently thinks. We rate WPP as a Buy.
